column2: with that many acres of old vehicles
column3: his chances looked pretty good. He glanced at his watch - 3:45 P.M.

column1: 1545|3:45 p.m.|It’s 3:45 p.m. and dark outside as I walk down the quiet hospice corridor
column2: looking for Luke O’Leary’s room. I find it - his name card is in the holder outside the door
column3: and the door is ajar. I hesitate. Afraid. There’s a small flow from inside. A curtain hangs partially across the doorway. I easy back the curtain and enter quietly.

it’s already three forty-five. You’ll never make it.”
“Is the backup bad?”
“Looks like a major accident up ahead. This is no ordinary traffic jam. We’ve hardly moved for quite a while.”
topped up with a glucose shot. Sleep is still 'black'
column3: completely unrefreshing. Last night I took a 16 mm. film of the first three hours
column4: screened it this morning at the lab. The first true-horror movie. I looked like a half-animated corpse. Woke 10:25. To sleep 3:45.
